Package mini1

Class LoopsInfinityAndBeyond

java.lang.Object
mini1.LoopsInfinityAndBeyond
public class LoopsInfinityAndBeyond
extends java.lang.Object
Utility class with a bunch of static methods for loop practice.
Author:
tancreti

  • Method Details

    • doubleChars

      public static java.lang.String doubleChars​(java.lang.String text)
      Returns a new string in which every character in the given string that is not already repeated consecutively is doubled.

      For example: 

      
 "attribute1" -> "aattrriibbuuttee11"
 "AAA Bonds" -> "AAA  BBoonnddss"
      Parameters:
      text - given starting string
      Returns:
      string with characters doubled

    • maxYear

      public static int maxYear​(java.lang.String data)
      Returns a year with the highest value, given a string containing pairs of years and values (doubles). If there are no pairs, the method returns -1. In the case of a tie, the first year with the highest value is returned. Assumes the given string follows the correct format.

      For example, given the following string, the year 1995 is returned. 

       1990 75.6 1991 110.6 1995 143.6 1997 62.3
      Parameters:
      data - given string containing year-value pairs
      Returns:
      first year associated with the highest value, or -1 if no pair given

    • collatzCounter

      public static int collatzCounter​(int n)
      Returns the number of iterations required until n is equal to 1, where each iteration updates n in the following way: 
           if n is even
         divide it in half
     else
         multiply n by three and add 1
      For example, given n == 6, the successive values of n would be 3, 10, 5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1, so the method returns 8. If n is less than 1, the method returns -1.

      (Remark: How do we know this won't be an infinite loop for some values of n? In general, we don't: in fact this is a well-known open problem in mathematics. However, it has been checked for numbers up to 10 billion, which covers the range of possible values of the Java int type.)

      Parameters:
      n - given starting number
      Returns:
      number of iterations required to reach n == 1, or -1 if n is not positive

    • doubleWords

      public static java.lang.String doubleWords​(java.lang.String text)
      Returns a new string in which every word in the given string is doubled. A word is defined as a contiguous group of non-space (i.e., ' ') characters that starts with an alphabetic letter and are surrounded by spaces and/or the start or end of the given string. Assumes the given string does not contain more than one consecutive white-space.

      For example: 

      
 "the time time" -> "the the time time time time"
 "The answer is 42." -> "The The answer answer is is 42."
 "A. runtime = 10ms" -> "A. A. runtime runtime = 10ms"
      Parameters:
      text - given starting string
      Returns:
      new string in which words are doubled

    • oneVowelRemoved

      public static boolean oneVowelRemoved​(java.lang.String s, java.lang.String t)
      Returns true if string t can be obtained from string s by removing exactly one vowel character. The vowels are the letters 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o' and 'u'. Vowels can be matched in either upper or lower case, for example, 'A' is treated the same as 'a'. If s contains no vowels the method returns false.

      For example: 

      
 "banana" and "banna" returns true
 "Apple" and "ppl" returns false
 "Apple" and "pple" returns true
      Parameters:
      s - longer string
      t - shorter string
      Returns:
      true if removing one vowel character from s produces the string t

    • ufo

      public static java.lang.String ufo​(java.lang.String space)
      Returns a new string in which a UFO pattern in the given string is shifted one character to the right. The UFO pattern starts with a '<', has one or more '=' and ends with a '>'. The pattern may wrap around from the end to the beginning of the string, for example "> <=". Any other characters from the given string remain in place. If the UFO moves over top of another character, that character is removed. If there are multiple UFO patterns, only the one that starts farthest to the left is moved.

      For example: 

      
 " <=>  *   . <=> " ->
 "  <=> *   . <=> "
 
 "   <=>*   .     " ->
 "    <=>   .     "
 
 ">.   x     .  <=" ->
 "=>   x     .   <"
 
 " <= <===>   .   " ->
 " <=  <===>  .   "
      Parameters:
      space - given string
      Returns:
      a new string with a UFO pattern moved one to the right

    • printX

      public static void printX​(int n)
      Prints a pattern of 2*n rows containing slashes, dashes and backslashes as illustrated below.

      When n <= 0 , prints nothing.

      n = 1 

       \/
 /\

      n = 2 

       \--/
 -\/
 -/\
 /--\

      n = 3 

       \----/
 -\--/
 --\/
 --/\
 -/--\
 /----\
      Parameters:
      n - number of rows in the output
